page.title: Complement Clauses
page.introduction:
This section considers various types of embedded clauses which are complements of main verbs, such as the following examples from English. (Embedded questions will be handled in
Questions.)

EnglishExample.exItem: I believe that Jill is my friend.
Jill insists that she is my friend.
I expect that Joe will come to the party.
I expect Joe to come to the party.
I will persuade Joe to come to the party.
Joe would hate for Sue to be at the party.
Joe tried to come to the party.

page.introduction:
The examples illustrate that main verb selects one or more particular types of complement clauses which can occur gramatically. For example, try cannot have a complement clause beginning with that and the subject of the embedded clause must be coreferent to the main clause subject and pro-dropped. Further, believe, insist and persuade cannot have a complement clause beginning with for and none of the verbs above can have an embedded question complement.
A second point the examples illustrate is that the presence of a particular complementizer determines the finiteness of the embedded verb which follows it. This evidence of subcategorization by the main verb for the complementizer and by the complementizer for the embedded verb form leads to the conclusion that the complementizer is the head of the embedded clause. Therefore, within X-Bar Theory, embedded clauses which have complementizers are CPs, which sit on top of the IP.
